body: LGTM
@jlowin this actually might be a precision problem. Did you check what sql was executed?

This is the commit message:

```
Expose task information in an API endpoint for
usage in other tools.
This API is located in the experimental endpoints.

Dear Airflow Maintainers,

Please accept this PR that addresses the following
issues:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-422

Testing Done:
- Added a simple unit test.

Expose task information in a web endpoint for
usage in other tools.

Closes #1740 from saguziel/master
```

Formally it does not adhere to the rules listed for a good commit. But worse maybe is that it is just a copy paste with some non information 'Dear Airflow Maintainers'?

The commit could better read:

```
This commit exposes the task information by JSON endpoint. It is marked experimental.

Closes #1740 from saguziel/master
```

What were you testing that required creating a pull request?

There might be other ways to test that I could help you with.
Oh ok, I have always just been using the PR body as a commit message
thanks for rebasing, can you explain why the env=test_env change is needed?

The `env=test_env` change is required because on MacOS X, the test was failing with `airflow.exceptions.AirflowException: Bash command failed`.

Something from the existing environment is needed for the command to succeed.

> Would you guys agree to only launch these dag tests for commits to the master branch

I think that's a good solution
No -- I just observed that the datetime part of the filter was causing the failure and assumed it was a casting issue. Interesting point. I will try to revisit.

> Something from the existing environment is needed for the command to succeed.
>  Hide all checks

hmm do you mind pinpointing which are needed? 

If it's possible to add 1 or 2 envars to `env` I think that would be better, otherwise if a lot are needed (and we understand why they are), then we can make the ssh command inherit the existing envars

I'm not sure which ones are needed, but from the python3 docs for subprocess.Popen:

> If env is not None, it must be a mapping that defines the environment variables for the new process; these are used instead of the default behavior of inheriting the current processâ€™ environment.
> Note: If specified, env must provide any variables required for the program to execute. On Windows, in order to run a side-by-side assembly the specified env must include a valid SystemRoot.

@zodiac because the default behavior when not specifying `env` inherits the current process' environment, I believe inheriting the existing envs in this case makes for a less brittle test.
@r39132 I've moved on to a different project, and don't know that I will have much time to work on this for the remainder of this calendar year. sorry.

I like the idea but for long logs the user needs to scroll all the way up to refresh, and all the way down to see new data.  I would prefer to put the refresh button underneath the log data.
lgtm

@dgies the commit title should not be more than 50 chars long (including jira id), and there should be a line break between title and commit message. Also commit message lines should not be longer  than 72 chars.
ðŸ‘
Cleaned up the commit message per @msumit
Unfortunately, test is failed at `test_config_throw_error_when_original_and_fallback_is_absent`.

I  thought I commented on this, but looks like I didn't.

I'd really like a "tail N lines" feature in the log view -- essentially, automatically refreshing the log every S seconds and showing the last N lines (both configurable) to the view port.

I +1 @dgies comment about moving the refresh button to the bottom of the screen. Manually refreshing is okay, but automatically refreshing feels like the right solution.

Looks like it is a pickle issue. I am not sure why it is adding "unusual_prefix_" before the module. When I removed -p from 

"airflow scheduler -p" command. it worked.

Do we know why this is happening?

Thanks

I think I see why one of the tests is broken.

The test failure occurs at: https://github.com/keybod/incubator-airflow/blob/f0964a5ff7c48160a629c1d8bd5f0531dbc50fac/tests/core.py#L706

The issue is that `core/fernet_key` is defined in both config and defaults.

Before, defaults and values got loaded in to the same place. Now they're loaded into separate places, so the `remove_option` is only removing one of them, not both.

I think you can fix this test by either: a) calling remove_option twice, or b) calling `conf.remove_option('core', 'fernet_key')` and then calling `conf.defaults.remove_option('core', 'fernet_key')`

Yes, you're right. However, the test calls module's function so It can't be access con.defaults object in `AirflowConfigParser`. 

Before we talked about not overriding `has_option` and `remove_option`, but My commit causes different behavior between module's function and class' function. Is it common?
Ya, most of the test would be great, if you want to strip out the other changes.

It's a little weird and, in fact, the module level functions are a bit weird to begin with, especially since they just pass through to the conf object. They could all be handled by variable assignment instead of function declaration. It might also be worth marking the module direct access as deprecated:

``` python

# Historical convenience functions to access config entries

load_test_config = conf.load_test_config
get = conf.get
getboolean = conf.getboolean
getfloat = conf.getfloat
getint = conf.getint
has_option = conf.has_option
remove_option = conf.remove_option
as_dict = conf.as_dict
set = conf.set

from zope.deprecation import deprecated as _deprecated
for func in [load_test_config, get, getboolean, getfloat, getint, has_option,
             remove_option, as_dict]:
    _deprecated(
        func,
        "Accessing configuration method '{f.__name__}' directly from "
        "the configuration module is deprecated. Please access the "
        "configuration from the 'configuration.conf' object via "
        "'conf.{f.__name__}'".format(f=func))
```
